utterances: As last-minute negotiations continue, the Senate is grinding toward a judicial showdown on two of President Bush's most controversial nominees to the federal bench.
Without a compromise, this fight may end with historic limitations on the power of the minority party in the Senate to block judicial nominations and other legislation.
Right now we're looking back on the congressional history of the filibuster and taking your questions about how this power has developed, how it may change in the future.
You're invited to join the discussion by calling us at (800) 989-TALK or sending us an e-mail at totn@npr.org.
Our guest is Charles Tiefer, professor of legislation at the University of Baltimore Law School.
Keith Perine is with us, judicial affairs reporter for Congressional Quarterly.
And, Charles, I wanted to ask you a little bit about the history of the filibuster and the fact that--tell us--first of all, the House at one point had this rule and changed it.
That's right.

Until 1890, for the first century that the Congress was in existence, in the House, the minority party could and did block action; indeed, the House minority paralyzed action a lot of the decades leading up to 1890, and then came a great struggle and the majority party changed the character of the House to what it has been since, quite unlike the Senate.
That is, the House does not allow--does not require consensus, does not allow the minority party to get in the way of the majority's agenda.
It functions, as we say, like a machine.
Yeah, well, there are a lot more people in the House, and so you can imagine that that may have been what was behind the instinct to get this change.
The Senate works on different operating system, as it were, doesn't it?
In a sense, there's more tradition involved than rules of the game, formal rules of the game.
That's exactly right.
The Senate has evolved with its limited number of members functioning like a club.
In the old days, an exclusive men's club, and since then, membership opened up.

And in the club, the people--the senators don't either assert their full powers of resistance or obstruction because that would be undignified and too militant to be a member of the club, and on the other hand, the majority does not bang the gavel and try to obtain machinelike powers that would also be inconsistent with the nature of the club.
A different kind of balance of decorum and dignity in this clublike atmosphere.

And, of course, the filibuster has been used on mostly controversial issues, to block the civil rights bill, for instance, and the Senate at that point didn't consider--the majority party didn't consider changing the rules about filibuster even though this was crucial legislation.

You know, inside the inscrutable black robes of the judiciary are, after all, human beings and they do have their own political leanings, religious beliefs.
They have personal experiences.

So we want to know how this cumulative material influences a judge's decision, and we thought we would step behind the bench and talk to Justice Alex Kozinski of the United States Court of Appeals from the 9th Circuit, Pasadena division.
Judge Kozinski joins us by phone from his office in Pasadena.
Judge Kozinski, welcome.
Pleasure to be here.
How do you separate--or do you separate your own political beliefs from the rulings you make?
Well, you have to understand that most cases, and much of what we deal with, is controlled by precedent one way or the other.

In other words, we have cases on point, and our job is to, you know, somewhat mechanically to extrapolate the correct result based on earlier applications of the same rule of law by the Supreme Court or our court.
Well...

So much of the process--you know, it's not the cases that you hear so much about, but most of what we do we are unanimous on, and whether it be Democrats or Republicans or conservatives or liberals, we reach a unanimous result in the overwhelming number of cases.

But for that popular or well-known minority of cases, certainly your views on the world and the views of your colleagues have to play a role, or this wouldn't be an issue, I suspect, in the Senate today.
I think that's right.

I think that's--but it's important to focus on the fact that there's unusual cases, and the cases that are not controlled by precedent, and the ones that really sort of hit home in terms of fundamental values, and there it seems to me that when there is no controlling authority, a part of what a judge has to look to--you have to look somewhere for guidance--has to be your own sense of life, your own sense of morality, your own sense of the proper relationship between the state and the individual.
